importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the CNN article's update, indicating the latest information on the incident involving Brett James' plane crash.
This marks the year Brett James achieved his breakthrough with the song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel,' which was featured on Carrie Underwood's debut album, launching his career in country music.
This is the date of the fatal plane crash, a pivotal event in the article that led to the NTSB investigation and public attention.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred on September 18, 2025, and is the focal point of the investigation into the cause of the crash.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, while attempting a visual approach to runway 7.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) identified that the aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, with no mechanical faults found in the plane.

James had requested a visual approach and incorrectly maintained a radio frequency, failing to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency, which led to a loss of communication with air traffic control.
The controller attempted to communicate that the pilot had not changed his radio frequency, but no further contact was made before the aircraft entered a spiral and crashed.

James was a highly influential songwriter who collaborated with major artists including Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, notably co-writing 'Out Last Night' and 'Jesus, Take the Wheel'.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the article, as the pilot whose plane crashed, leading to the investigation and public attention.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB conducted the preliminary investigation into the plane crash, providing official findings on the cause and contributing to public understanding of the incident.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A single-engine general aviation aircraft model
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The specific plane model involved in the crash, with no mechanical issues found, indicating the crash was due to pilot or procedural error.

namedEntities.name: Franklin, North Carolina

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The geographic location of the crash, approximately 270 miles southeast of Nashville, is key to understanding the incident's context and regional impact.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key collaborator of Brett James, illustrating his strong presence in the country music community.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to communicate location when no tower control is present
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to change his radio frequency, resulting in a communication breakdown with air traffic control, a key factor in the crash.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) released a preliminary report stating that Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina. His single-engine Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' during a visual approach to runway 7 after James failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF) despite being instructed to do so. Air traffic control attempted to communicate that he had not changed the frequency, but there was no further contact. The NTSB found no mechanical issues with the plane. James, a highly influential songwriter, had collaborated with major artists including Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, notably co-writing hits such as 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' and 'Out Last Night,' which helped launch his career.
title: Songwriter Brett James' Plane Crashes After Radio Communication Failure
